awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Non-Additive Network Routing and Assignment Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Network assignment models are widely used to study the flow of commodities on infrastructure with a network structure (such as roadway drivers or freight shipments) and form the basis of transportation planning for urban areas.  Currently, most network assignment models assume that the travel costs for a route is simply the sum of the travel costs of the roadway segments comprising that route. While true for some costs (like trip time), this assumption is invalid when accounting for costs due to unreliability, late arrival penalties, and risk preferences. This award will develop new network assignment models which can capture broader user objectives in route choice decision making, particularly related to reliability.  Accurately representing such objectives in network optimization models will lead to better infrastructure planning and management strategies in large-scale urban areas, ultimately leading to reduced emissions and other related health benefits. The research will support participation and training of graduate and undergraduate students from minority and underrepresented groups in research. The results of this research will be incorporated into several undergraduate and graduate courses and high school lesson plans. 

This project will investigate efficient algorithms for different variants of non-additive shortest path, minimum cost flow, and traffic assignment problems, with potential applications in freight.  These algorithms will exploit and advance recent progress in cutting plane and decomposition-based global optimization algorithms, and the underlying network structure. The project has three specific research aims: (i) Develop efficient solution algorithms for non-additive shortest path variants and their time-dependent extensions. (ii) Develop mathematical models and solution algorithms for non-additive network flow models. (iii) Develop analytical formulation and solution algorithm for the non-additive traffic assignment problem. The researched work draws on and integrates principles of network optimization, transportation network analysis, bi-criterion search, and global optimization. The key contribution of this work is the potential to exploit the synergies and integrate theoretically rigorous decomposition and cutting plane based algorithms developed for convex mixed integer nonlinear programs and existing network optimization algorithms.

por.por_cntn:
Almost all transportation and freight infrastructure has a network structure. We can study transportation and freight systems' performance using a particular class of mathematical models called network flow models.  Network flow models capture the movement of people and goods on routes in a network while incurring costs. We can use network flow models to study how individual travelers and goods' routing decisions affect overall system performance. A key aspect affecting network flow models' accuracy is effectively capturing factors that influence how people or commodities choose routes. A majority of the network flow models assume that the travel costs incurred are additive.  For example, if you are traveling from home to the airport and stop by your workplace to pick up documents, then the travel time from home to the airport is the sum of travel times from home to work and work to the airport. However, there are factors other than travel time that affect travelers' choice of routes. This is particularly applicable when there is uncertainty, which is endemic to transportation and freight networks – travel times and costs vary significantly from day-to-day due to accidents, weather, etc. For example, when picking a route to the airport, a traveler might choose a more reliable route, which need not always be the shortest route. In such cases, the additivity assumption is not valid. Travel time reliability from home to the airport is not the sum of travel time reliability from home to work and work to the airport. This assumption is valid in several other contexts. With electric vehicles, the range anxiety effect produces nonlinearities in the valuation of travel distance.  In eco-routing problems, the emissions produced on a link depends on engine temperature, a function of the distance previously traveled.  In freight, overtime pay for drivers and early/late penalties can also prevent separating path cost into a sum of link costs. This project develops several efficient algorithms that can solve network flow problems under this non-additivity assumption.
In this project, we developed algorithms for several classes of non-additive network flow problems which have broad applications. We developed a model and solution method for choosing dynamically varying toll prices when travelers receive traffic information through GPS and cell phones to minimize congestion in the system. The research team developed algorithms that minimize not just average travel costs but also the standard deviation of travel costs. We developed a model and algorithm to determine which roadways to install sensors to minimize an adversary attempt to push maximum flow through the network. This framework can be used for devising strategies for various problems, including aiding anti-drug efforts, maintenance scheduling of road infrastructure, and improving the reliability of supply-chain networks. We also developed several models to appropriately account for the uncertainty in demand for commodities in the supply chain when considering both locations of warehouses and inventories. The research in this project also help in evaluating the efficiency and viability of the incorporation of new technologies such as drones in making freight deliveries.


The research will advance transportation planning by developing network models that can capture user preferences and uncertainty more accurately. More accurate modeling of user preferences will lead to better estimates of flow and level of service metrics leading to the development of effective planning and operational strategies from the perspective of congestion management, fuel savings, and reduction in emissions.
The project exposed and trained two graduate students, four undergraduates, and one high school student in research. Three out of the four undergraduates were women. We have also developed several tutorials and training materials that have been uploaded on our websites. In addition, the research results have been incorporated into a textbook on transportation network analysis. The textbook is available for free on our websites. We are currently updating the textbook based on feedback obtained from experts.
